characteristics.description: Emphasizes traditional elements of bluegrass music, contrasting with progressive bluegrass.

song_types: Tunes with Simple Traditional Chord Progressions
instruments_usage: Acoustic Instruments similar to those used by Bill Monroe and his Blue Grass Boys band in the late 1940s
Multiple guitars or fiddles in a band
guitar_role: Rarely takes the lead, except in gospel-based songs
melodies_and_lyrics: Commonly in the key of G or other keys
performance_practices: No use of electrically amplified instruments
Acoustic instruments are miked during stage performances before larger audiences

mandolin_standard.name: Bill Monroe
mandolin_standard.contribution: Set the standard for mandolin playing style in traditional bluegrass

fiddling_standard.name: Kenny Baker
fiddling_standard.contribution: Set the standard for fiddling in traditional bluegrass

banjo_playing.name: Earl Scruggs
banjo_playing.contribution: Developed the three-finger style banjo playing

traditional_views: Some traditional musicians do not consider progressive bluegrass to be true 'bluegrass'
Some believe bluegrass must be styled directly after Bill Monroe's bands

stylistic_divergences.description: Center on which first generation bands contemporary musicians draw inspiration from.

followers: Various local bands across the country
